introduction.p: An improper fraction is one in which the numerator is larger than the denominator.

statement.p: Write an improper fraction for the sum ~2 + \dfrac{3}{8}

solution.p: We write the whole number with the same denominator as the fraction. Thus, \blert{2} + \dfrac{3}{8} = \blert{\dfrac{16}{8}}+\dfrac{3}{8} = \dfrac{16+3}{8} = \dfrac{19}{8}

statement.p: Write an improper fraction for the difference ~3 - \dfrac{1}{5}

solution.p: We write the whole number with the same denominator as the fraction. Thus, \blert{3} - \dfrac{1}{5} = \blert{\dfrac{15}{5}}-\dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{15-1}{5} = \dfrac{14}{5}

introduction.p: The first step in adding unlike fractions is to find the lowest common denominator, or LCD.

statement.p: Find the LCD for the fractions ~\dfrac{2}{5} + \dfrac{3}{10}

solution.p: We factor each denominator and line up any common factors vertically. We use one factor from each column in the LCD. 15 \amp = \blert{3} ~~~\cdot~~~ 5 10 \amp = ~~~~~~~~~~~~\blert{5}~~~\cdot~~~\blert{2} The LCD is 3 \cdot 5\cdot 2, or 30.

statement.p: Find the LCD for the fractions ~\dfrac{5}{6a} - \dfrac{2}{9a^2}

solution.p: We factor each denominator and line up any common factors vertically. We use one factor from each column in the LCD. 6a \amp = \blert{2}~~~\cdot~~~ 3~~~\cdot~~~ a 9a^2 \amp = ~~~~~~~~~~~~\blert{3}~~~\cdot~~~\blert{3}~~~\cdot~~~ \blert{a}~~~\cdot~~~ \blert{a} The LCd is 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot a \cdot a, or 18a^2.

introduction.p: Before we can add unlike fractions, we must build each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD as denominator.

statement.p: Write an equivalent fraction with the new denominator: ~\dfrac{3}{s} = \dfrac{?}{2s^2}

solution.p: We first find the building factor for the fraction: what must we mulitply the old denominator by to get the new denominator? We factor the new denominator to see what factors are missing.

The new denominator is 2 \cdot s \cdot 3, so we need to multiply the old denominator by 2s. This is the building factor. We multiply top and bottom of the old fraction by the building factor: \dfrac{3}{s} \cdot \blert{\dfrac{2s}{2s}} = \dfrac{6}{2s^2}

statement.p: Write an equivalent fraction with the new denominator: ~\dfrac{2}{t+1} = \dfrac{?}{t^2+t}

solution.p: The new denominator factors as t(t+1), so the building factor is t. We multiply top and bottom of the old fraction by t to obtain: \dfrac{2}{t+1} \cdot \blert{\dfrac{t}{t}} = \dfrac{2t}{t^2+t}
